title: Command Line Usage
text: coordinates_vector: R vector strings. string denotes primary axis, structure ‘atom1 atom2’, 3D vector atom1 atom2 define sterimol’s primary axis. function expects least one primary axis, one primary axis wanted, user defines argument: 'atom1 atom2' use multiple axes, user defines set axes argument: c('atom1 atom2', 'atom3 atom4') example: 1. say user wants compute sterimol values axis 1-2 say user wants compute sterimol values axes 1-2 1-3 CPK: Users can avoid default use Pyykko’s covalent radii apply CPK values setting CPK = T. example: say user wants compute sterimol values axes 1-2 1-3, CPK values only_sub: default setting makes sure sterimol values given substituent mind. steRimol uses graph-based search atoms stem primary axis, uses remaining substructure alone. Users can avoid step setting only_sub = F drop: optional dropping substructure substituent mind. Users can ask sterimol drop atoms directly connected atom ‘’ onward. example , drop set 15. Note drop, user input integer character. enough indicate first atom substructure dropped. Multiple substructures can dropped using drop = c(atom, another atom, ...).
code: # explicitly  sterimol.multi(coordinates_vector = '1 2')  # implicitly  sterimol.multi('1 2') # explicitly  sterimol.multi(coordinates_vector = c('1 2', '1 3'))  # implicitly  sterimol.multi(c('1 2', '1 3')) # explicitly  sterimol.multi(coordinates_vector = c('1 2', '1 3'), CPK = T)  # implicitly  sterimol.multi(c('1 2', '1 3'), T) # CPK is either T or F  # explicitly  sterimol.multi(coordinates_vector = c('1 2', '1 3'), CPK, only_sub = F)  # implicitly  sterimol.multi(c('1 2', '1 3'), CPK, F) # CPK is either T or F # only_sub is set to T, but can be F as well  # explicitly  sterimol.multi(coordinates_vector = '3 1', CPK, only_sub = T, drop = 15)  # implicitly  sterimol.multi('3 1', CPK, T, 15)

title: Command Line Usage
code: # Dipole Moment = DM # Coordinate System = CS  # To extract DM as it is given in Gaussian, use:  dip.gaussian.multi() # with no arguments  # To extract the DM, with a change of CS, such that atom 1 will be the origin, # atom 2 will set the y direction, and atom 3 will set the xy plane, use:  # explicitly dip.gaussian.multi(coor_atoms = '1 2 3')  # implicitly  dip.gaussina.multi('1 2 3')  # To use the center of mass of the 'basic' structure, using the CS '1 2 3', use:  # explicitly dip.gaussian.multi(coor_atoms = '1 2 3', center_of_mass = T)  # implicitly  dip.gaussina.multi('1 2 3', T)  # To use the center of mass of a substructure,  # using the CS '3 1 8', and the center of mass of atoms 3-8, use:  # explicitly dip.gaussian.multi(coor_atoms = '1 2 3',                 center_of_mass = F,                  center_of_mass_substructure = T,                 sub_atoms = '3 4 5 6 7 8')  # implicitly  dip.gaussina.multi('1 2 3', F, T, '3 4 5 6 7 8')  # To use the center of mass of several substructures,  # using the CS '3 1 8', and the center of mass of atoms 3-8,  # and that of atoms 1-3, use:  # explicitly dip.gaussian.multi(coor_atoms = '1 2 3',                 center_of_mass = F,                  center_of_mass_substructure = T,                 sub_atoms = c('3 4 5 6 7 8', '1 2 3'))  # implicitly  dip.gaussina.multi('1 2 3', F, T, c('3 4 5 6 7 8', '1 2 3'))  # See documentation - in R console: ?dip.gaussian.df() ?dip.gaussian.multi()

code: ### Function Structure ### simi.sampler(   data,   class,   compare.with = 0,   plot = F,   sample.size = min(summary(as.factor(data$class))) ) # Load data data <- data.frame(data.table::fread('path/to/downloaded/Logistic_Dataset_Example.csv'))  # Assuming the first column of data is molecule names row.names(data) <- data[, 1]  # Remove after assigning row names data <- data[, -1]  # Factor the 'class' column (make categorical)   data$class <- as.factor(data$class) simi.sampler(data = data, class = 1, plot = T)  # Gives the vector of samples as output (row numbers to be sampled)  [1]  1  7  8 12 13 15 18 19 20 21 22
